facts.text: Shri Avtar Narain Gujral born on June 4, 1892, thus over sixty years old on August 29, 1953.
On August 29, 1953, Government of Punjab notified appointment of Shri Avtar Narain Gujral as Industrial Tribunal for Punjab under section 7 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
On February 14, 1955, Government of Punjab referred disputes between appellant and respondents to Industrial Tribunal Punjab, Jullundur, numbered as Reference No. 3 of 1955.

Industrial Disputes (Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1956 (Act 36 of 1956) came into force on March 10, 1957, repealing section 7 and replacing with sections 7A, 7B, 7C; section 30 saves pending proceedings.

On April 19, 1957, Punjab Government issued notification under section 30 of Act 36/1956 extending life of old Tribunal constituted under repealed section 7 until October 31, 1957 or disposal of pending disputes, and continuing Shri A.N. Gujral as Member.

On April 19, 1957, Punjab Government constituted new Industrial Tribunal at Jullundur under section 7A and appointed Shri A.N. Gujral as Presiding Officer from date of gazette publication up to June 3, 1957.
Punjab Legislature enacted Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957, amending section 7C(b) to raise retirement age from 65 to 67 years.

Industrial Disputes (Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions) (Punjab Amendment) Act 9 of 1957 introduced section 30(2) in Act 36/1956 authorizing reconstitution of ended Tribunals for pending disputes.

On October 31, 1957, Punjab Government transferred pending matters including Reference No. 3 of 1955 from old Tribunal to new Tribunal under section 33B(1) and section 30 as amended; renumbered as Reference No. 30 of 1957.
Shri A.N. Gujral tenure extended multiple times up to June 3, 1959.
Shri A.N. Gujral retired on June 3, 1959.
Punjab Government appointed Sri Kesho Ram Passey, retired Judge of Punjab High Court, as Presiding Officer of Industrial Tribunal, Jullundur.
On September 4, 1959, appellant filed application raising preliminary objections to jurisdiction before new Presiding Officer.
On September 11, 1959, Industrial Tribunal overruled preliminary objections and posted matter for hearing on merits.
Appeal by special leave filed against Tribunal's order dated September 11, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether Shri A.N. Gujral qualified for appointment as Tribunal under s.7(3)(c) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on August 29, 1953, being over 60 years old, in light of Art.217 Constitution.
Whether notifications dated April 19, 1957 extending old Tribunal and appointing/continuing Shri A.N. Gujral valid under s.30 of Act 36/1956.
Whether Punjab Act 8 of 1957 raising retirement age to 67 years void under Art.14 as benefiting single individual Shri A.N. Gujral.
Whether transfer notification dated October 31, 1957 valid under s.30(2) as amended by Punjab Act 9/1957, including retrospective operation for pre-March 10, 1957 pendings.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shri A.N. Gujral not qualified under s.7(3)(c) as over 60 years on appointment date; age 60 bar in Art.217(1) is implied qualification.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.7(3)(c); Constitution Art.217

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification April 19, 1957 continuing Shri A.N. Gujral as Member after s.7 repeal unauthorised by s.30 Act 36/1956.
Punjab Act 8/1957 void under Art.14 as intended to benefit single individual Shri A.N. Gujral by raising retirement age.
Transfer October 31, 1957 invalid as target Tribunal invalidly constituted and s.30(2) lacks retrospective operation for pre-March 10, 1957 pendings; Punjab Act 9/1957 not retrospective.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.33B(1); Act 36/1956 s.30(2); Punjab Act 9/1957

court_reasoning.text: Art.217(1) age 60 limit is condition on duration of office, not qualification for appointment; distinction between age condition and experience-based qualifications in Art.217(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Person over 60 qualified under s.7(3)(c) if meets Art.217(2) criteria.

court_reasoning.text: s.7(3)(a),(b) allow retired judges over 60; no basis to imply age bar in (c) for advocates.
s.30 Act 36/1956 saves and extends old Tribunals including members; notification April 19, 1957 authorised.
Punjab Act 8/1957 general application raising age to 67 for all; not discriminatory under Art.14 despite individual occasion.
s.30(2) entirely retrospective to cover pre-commencement pendings unable to be disposed due to Tribunal end.

holdings.text: s.7(3)(c) does not import age qualification from Art.217(1); appointment of Shri A.N. Gujral on 29.8.1953 valid.
Notifications April 19, 1957 valid under s.30 Act 36/1956.
Punjab Act 8/1957 not violative of Art.14.
Transfer notification October 31, 1957 valid under s.30(2) with retrospective effect.

precedents_cited.relevance: Age 60 in Art.217(1) not qualification for High Court Judge appointment; applied to Advocate-General and s.7(3)(c).
Appointment of Shri A.N. Gujral under s.7(3)(c) valid despite age over 60.
Legislation singling out individuals for adverse treatment violates Art.14; unlike general Punjab Act 8/1957.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for Tribunal; reference, constitution, transfer of disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1956 (Act 36/1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Savings for pending proceedings; extension and transfer of old Tribunals.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Punjab Amendment) Act 8 of 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Raised retirement age to 67 years; held valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; High Court Judge qualifications, tenure, age not bar to appointment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected all preliminary objections raised by appellant regarding validity of Tribunal's constitution, appointments, extensions, and transfer of reference; upheld Industrial Tribunal's order dated September 11, 1959 overruling objections.

key_quotes.text: "We agree that there is implicit in Art. 217(1) a prohibition against appointment as a Judge of a person who has attained the age of sixty years. But in our view, that is in the nature of a condition governing the appointment to the office-not a qualification".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing age as condition not qualification under s.7(3)(c).

key_quotes.text: "The insertion of age qualification in s.7C is more consistent with an intention on the part of the Legislature to add... a new provision prescribing the age of retirement for Members."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects inference of implicit age bar in original s.7(3)(c).
